member.name: T:Cloo.Bindings.ComputeContextNotifier
member.summary: A callback function that can be registered by the application to report information on errors that occur in the .
member.param: A pointer to binary data that is returned by the OpenCL implementation that can be used to log additional information helpful in debugging the error.
The size of the binary data that is returned by the OpenCL.
The pointer to the optional user data specified in argument of constructor.
member.remarks: This callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe.

member.name: T:Cloo.Bindings.ComputeProgramBuildNotifier
member.summary: A callback function that can be registered by the application to report the build status.
member.param: The handle of the being built.
The pointer to the optional user data specified in argument of .
member.remarks: This callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe.

members.member:
A callback function that can be registered by the application.
The memory object being deleted. When the user callback is called, this memory object is not longer valid. is only provided for reference purposes. A pointer to user supplied data. /// This callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe.

The event callback function that can be registered by the application.
The event object for which the callback function is invoked. Represents the execution status of the command for which this callback function is invoked. If the callback is called as the result of the command associated with the event being abnormally terminated, an appropriate error code for the error that caused the termination will be passed to instead. A pointer to user supplied data. /// This callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe.

member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the . is restricted to value types and structs containing such types.
member.remarks: A memory object that stores a linear collection of bytes. Buffer objects are accessible using a pointer in a kernel executing on a device.

member.summary: Creates a new .
member.param: A bit-field that is used to specify allocation and usage information about the .
member.remarks: Note, that cannot be an "immediate" parameter, i.e.: new T[100], because it could be quickly collected by the GC causing Cloo to send and invalid reference to OpenCL.

member.summary: Creates a new from an existing OpenGL buffer object.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the . should match the type of the elements in the OpenGL buffer.
member.param: A bit-field that is used to specify usage information about the . Only , and are allowed.
The OpenGL buffer object id to use for the creation of the .

member.name: T:Cloo.ComputeCommandQueue
member.summary: Represents an OpenCL command queue.
member.remarks: A command queue is an object that holds commands that will be executed on a specific device. The command queue is created on a specific device in a context. Commands to a command queue are queued in-order but may be executed in-order or out-of-order.

member.param: A collection of events that need to complete before this particular command can be executed. If is not null a new event identifying this command is attached to the end of the collection.

member.summary: Enqueues a command to copy a 2D or 3D region of elements between two buffers.
member.typeparam: The type of data in the buffers.
member.param: The element position where reading starts.
The element position where writing starts.
The region of elements to copy.
The size of the source buffer row in bytes. If set to zero then equals region.X * sizeof(T).
The size of the source buffer 2D slice in bytes. If set to zero then equals region.Y * sizeof(T) * sourceRowPitch.
The size of the destination buffer row in bytes. If set to zero then equals region.X * sizeof(T).
The size of the destination buffer 2D slice in bytes. If set to zero then equals region.Y * sizeof(T) * destinationRowPitch.

A collection of events that need to complete before this particular command can be executed. If is not null or read-only a new identifying this command is created and attached to the end of the collection.
member.remarks: Requires OpenCL 1.1.

member.name: M:Cloo.ComputeCommandQueue.Execute(Cloo.ComputeKernel,System.Int64[],System.Int64[],System.Int64[],System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Cloo.ComputeEventBase})
member.summary: Enqueues a command to execute a range of s in parallel.
member.param: An array of values that describe the offset used to calculate the global ID of a work-item instead of having the global IDs always start at offset (0, 0,... 0).

An array of values that describe the number of global work-items in dimensions that will execute the kernel function. The total number of global work-items is computed as global_work_size[0] *...* global_work_size[work_dim - 1].

An array of values that describe the number of work-items that make up a work-group (also referred to as the size of the work-group) that will execute the . The total number of work-items in a work-group is computed as local_work_size[0] *... * local_work_size[work_dim - 1].

A collection of events that need to complete before this particular command can be executed. If is not null or read-only a new identifying this command is created and attached to the end of the collection.

member.name: M:Cloo.ComputeContext.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Cloo.ComputeDevice},Cloo.ComputeContextPropertyList,Cloo.Bindings.ComputeContextNotifier,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates a new on a collection of s.
member.param: A collection of s to associate with the .

A delegate instance that refers to a notification routine. This routine is a callback function that will be used by the OpenCL implementation to report information on errors that occur in the . The callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe and that the delegate instance doesn't get collected by the Garbage Collector until is disposed. If is null, no callback function is registered.
Optional user data that will be passed to .

member.name: T:Cloo.ComputeDevice
member.summary: Represents an OpenCL device.
member.value: A device is a collection of compute units. A command queue is used to queue commands to a device. Examples of commands include executing kernels, or reading and writing memory objects. OpenCL devices typically correspond to a GPU, a multi-core CPU, and other processors such as DSPs and the Cell/B.E. processor.

member.summary: Sets an argument of the (no argument tracking).
member.param: The size of the argument data in bytes.
A pointer to the data that should be used as the argument value.

Arguments to the kernel are referred by indices that go from 0 for the leftmost argument to n-1, where n is the total number of arguments declared by the kernel.

member.name: M:Cloo.ComputeProgram.Build(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Cloo.ComputeDevice},System.String,Cloo.Bindings.ComputeProgramBuildNotifier,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Builds (compiles and links) a program executable from the program source or binary for all or some of the .
member.param: A subset or all of . If is null, the executable is built for every item of for which a source or a binary has been loaded.
A set of options for the OpenCL compiler.

A delegate instance that represents a reference to a notification routine. This routine is a callback function that an application can register and which will be called when the program executable has been built (successfully or unsuccessfully). If is not null, does not need to wait for the build to complete and can return immediately. If is null, does not return until the build has completed. The callback function may be called asynchronously by the OpenCL implementation. It is the application's responsibility to ensure that the callback function is thread-safe and that the delegate instance doesn't get collected by the Garbage Collector until the build operation triggers the callback.
Optional user data that will be passed to .

members.member:
* Allows multiple threads to gather at a point before proceeding.
*
* @author Thomas W. Christopher (Tools of Computing LLC)
* @version 0.2 Beta
* Number of threads that still must gather.
* Number of threads that still must gather.
* Total number of threads that must gather.

* Creates a Barrier at which n threads may repeatedly gather.
*
* @param n total number of threads that must gather.

* Is called by a thread to wait for the rest of the n threads to gather
* before the set of threads may continue executing.
*
* @throws InterruptedException If interrupted while waiting.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Host.DeviceTypeInfo
member.summary: For a class, and instance of which we want to move onto the Device, we create a new representation of the instance on the device. This is the DeviceType, which basically has reference type fields replaced by IntPtrs to device memory.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper
member.summary: Helper that can create an instance of a class or struct on the device, given an instance of a Cudafyable class on the CPU. Any reference type members of the class become pointers to the member (in device memory). Any value type members must be blittable. A one-to-one map of objects on the host and objects on the device is maintained so that instances that share an array on the host share the same array on the device.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.deviceObjectFromHostObject
member.summary: This provides a mapping of the host object to the object that encapsulates the device pointer (via _deviceMemory).

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.TryGetDeviceObjectFromHostObject(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the device object that is mapped to the host object.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.TryGetDeviceMemoryFromHostObject(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the device pointer for the device object that is mapped to the host object.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.CreateDeviceObject``1(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU,``0)
member.summary: Creates a version of hostObject on the device with any fields which are reference types converted to pointers to device memory (IntPtrs) and any arrays copied to the device.
member.returns: THe device object (that can then be used in kernal calls).

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.UpdateFromDevice``1(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU,``0)
member.summary: Update any array fields of an object where the arrays are on the device.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.CopyReferenceTypeFieldsToDevice``1(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU,``0)
member.summary: Copies any reference type fields (e.g. arrays) of the object to the device.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.CreateDeviceType(System.Type)
member.summary: Create type that contains pointers to device arrays.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DeviceClassHelper.GetFieldsStandardLayout(System.Type)
member.summary: Get fields in the same order in which these would appear in memory for the device object (i.e. standard layout rules).

member.name: T:Cudafy.Host.DynamicLauncher
member.summary: Allows GPU functions to be called using dynamic language run-time. For example: gpgpu.Launch(16, 16).myGPUFunction(x, y, res)

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DynamicLauncher.#ctor(Cudafy.Host.GPGPU)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Host.DynamicLauncher.TryInvokeMember(System.Dynamic.InvokeMemberBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that invoke a member. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as calling a method.
member.param: Provides information about the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleMethod". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.

The arguments that are passed to the object member during the invoke operation. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is derived from the class, is equal to 100.
The result of the member invocation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.summary: Returns the enumeration of all global functions.
member.returns: A sequence that contains global function names.

member.summary: Performs the banded matrix-vector multiplication. y = alpha * op(A) * x + beta * y
member.param: number of rows of matrix A.
number of columns of matrix A.
number of subdiagonals of matrix A.
number of superdiagonals of matrix A.
array of dimentions (kl + ku + 1) * n. This must be packed by column by column method.
vector with n elements if trans = N, m elements otherwise.

operation op(A) that is non- or(conj.) transpose.
leading dimension of two-dimensional array used to store matrix A. This typically be kl + ku + 1.
stride between consecutive elements of x.
stride between consecutive elements of y.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.eCompatibilityMode
member.summary: FFTW compatibility mode.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.eCompatibilityMode.FFTW_Padding
member.summary: Inserts extra padding between packed in-place transforms for batched transforms with power-of-2 size. (default)

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.eCompatibilityMode.FFTW_Asymmetric
member.summary: Guarantees FFTW-compatible output for non-symmetric complex inputs for transforms with power-of-2 size. This is only useful for artificial (i.e. random) datasets as actual data will always be symmetric if it has come from the real plane. If you don't understand what this means, you probably don't have to use it.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.eCompatibilityMode.FFTW_All
member.summary: For convenience, enables all FFTW compatibility modes at once.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags
member.summary: FFTW planner flags

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.Measure
member.summary: Tells FFTW to find an optimized plan by actually computing several FFTs and measuring their execution time. Depending on your machine, this can take some time (often a few seconds). Default (0x0).

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.DestroyInput
member.summary: Specifies that an out-of-place transform is allowed to overwrite its input array with arbitrary data; this can sometimes allow more efficient algorithms to be employed.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.Unaligned
member.summary: Rarely used. Specifies that the algorithm may not impose any unusual alignment requirements on the input/output arrays (i.e. no SIMD). This flag is normally not necessary, since the planner automatically detects misaligned arrays. The only use for this flag is if you want to use the guru interface to execute a given plan on a different array that may not be aligned like the original.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.ConserveMemory
member.summary: Not used.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.Exhaustive
member.summary: Like Patient, but considers an even wider range of algorithms, including many that we think are unlikely to be fast, to produce the most optimal plan but with a substantially increased planning time.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.PreserveInput
member.summary: Specifies that an out-of-place transform must not change its input array.
member.remarks: This is ordinarily the default, except for c2r and hc2r (i.e. complex-to-real) transforms for which DestroyInput is the default. In the latter cases, passing PreserveInput will attempt to use algorithms that do not destroy the input, at the expense of worse performance; for multi-dimensional c2r transforms, however, no input-preserving algorithms are implemented and the planner will return null if one is requested.

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.Patient
member.summary: Like Measure, but considers a wider range of algorithms and often produces a “more optimal” plan (especially for large transforms), but at the expense of several times longer planning time (especially for large transforms).

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_flags.Estimate
member.summary: Specifies that, instead of actual measurements of different algorithms, a simple heuristic is used to pick a (probably sub-optimal) plan quickly. With this flag, the input/output arrays are not overwritten during planning.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_direction
member.summary: Defines direction of operation

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_direction.Forward
member.summary: Computes a regular DFT

member.name: F:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_direction.Backward
member.summary: Computes the inverse DFT

member.name: T:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw_kind
member.summary: Kinds of real-to-real transforms

member.summary: Contains the Basic Interface FFTW functions for double-precision (double) operations

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.malloc(System.Int32)
member.summary: Allocates FFTW-optimized unmanaged memory

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.free(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Deallocates memory allocated by FFTW malloc

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.destroy_plan(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Deallocates an FFTW plan and all associated resources
member.param: Pointer to the plan to release

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.cleanup
member.summary: Clears all memory used by FFTW, resets it to initial state. Does not replace destroy_plan and free
member.remarks: After calling fftw_cleanup, all existing plans become undefined, and you should not attempt to execute them nor to destroy them. You can however create and execute/destroy new plans, in which case FFTW starts accumulating wisdom information again. fftw_cleanup does not deallocate your plans; you should still call fftw_destroy_plan for this purpose.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.set_timelimit(System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the maximum time that can be used by the planner.
member.remarks: This function instructs FFTW to spend at most seconds seconds (approximately) in the planner. If seconds == -1.0 (the default value), then planning time is unbounded. Otherwise, FFTW plans with a progressively wider range of algorithms until the the given time limit is reached or the given range of algorithms is explored, returning the best available plan. For example, specifying fftw_flags.Patient first plans in Estimate mode, then in Measure mode, then finally (time permitting) in Patient. If fftw_flags.Exhaustive is specified instead, the planner will further progress to Exhaustive mode.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftw.execute(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Executes an FFTW plan, provided that the input and output arrays still exist
member.param: Pointer to the plan to execute
member.remarks: execute (and equivalents) is the only function in FFTW guaranteed to be thread-safe.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftwf.cleanup
member.summary: Clears all memory used by FFTW, resets it to initial state. Does not replace destroy_plan and free
member.remarks: After calling fftw_cleanup, all existing plans become undefined, and you should not attempt to execute them nor to destroy them. You can however create and execute/destroy new plans, in which case FFTW starts accumulating wisdom information again. fftw_cleanup does not deallocate your plans; you should still call fftw_destroy_plan for this purpose.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Maths.FFT.fftwf.set_timelimit(System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the maximum time that can be used by the planner.
member.remarks: This function instructs FFTW to spend at most seconds seconds (approximately) in the planner. If seconds == -1.0 (the default value), then planning time is unbounded. Otherwise, FFTW plans with a progressively wider range of algorithms until the the given time limit is reached or the given range of algorithms is explored, returning the best available plan. For example, specifying fftw_flags.Patient first plans in Estimate mode, then in Measure mode, then finally (time permitting) in Patient. If fftw_flags.Exhaustive is specified instead, the planner will further progress to Exhaustive mode.

member.param: Pointer to the plan to execute
member.remarks: execute (and equivalents) is the only function in FFTW guaranteed to be thread-safe.

member.summary: Converts the array containing the uncompressed row indices (corresponding to COO format) into an array of compressed row pointers (corresponding to CSR format). It can also be used to convert the array containing the uncompressed column indices (corresponding to COO format) into an array of column pointers (corresponding to CSC format).

number of rows of the matrix A; m must be at least zero.

member.name: T:Cudafy.Maths.SPARSE.cusparseHandle
member.summary: This is a pointer type to an opaque CUSPARSE context, which the user must initialize by calling cusparseCreate() prior to calling any other library function. The Handle created and retruned by cusparseCreate() must be passed to every CUSPARSE function.

member.name: M:Cudafy.Translator.CudafyTranslator.Cudafy
member.summary: Tries to use a previous serialized CudafyModule else cudafies and compiles the type in which the calling method is located. CUDA architecture is 2.0; platform is set to the current application's (x86 or x64); and the CUDA version is the latest official release found on the current machine.

member.summary: Tries to use a previous serialized CudafyModule else cudafies and compiles the type in which the calling method is located. CUDA architecture is as specified; platform is set to the current application's (x86 or x64); and the CUDA version is the latest official release found on the current machine.

member.summary: Retrieves all top-level classes.

Language-specific rules for how namespace names are compared

member.summary: Gets a namespace.

member.returns: The full name of the namespace, if it exists; or null if the namespace does not exist.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.TypeSystem.ITypeResolveContext.Synchronize
member.summary: Returns a that represents the same context as this instance, but cannot be modified by other threads. The ISynchronizedTypeResolveContext must be disposed from the same thread that called this method when it is no longer used.
member.remarks: A simple implementation might enter a ReaderWriterLock when the synchronized context is created, and releases the lock when Dispose() is called. However, implementations based on immutable data structures are also possible.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.TypeSystem.ITypeResolveContext.CacheManager
member.summary: Returns the cache manager associated with this resolve context, or null if caching is not allowed. Whenever the resolve context changes in some way, this property must return a new object to ensure that old caches are cleared.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.TypeSystem.ISynchronizedTypeResolveContext
member.summary: Context representing the set of assemblies in which a type is being searched. Guarantees that the list of types available in the context is not changed until Dispose() is called. The Dispose() method must be called from the same thread that create the ISynchronizedTypeResolveContext.
member.remarks:
A simple implementation might enter a ReaderWriterLock when the synchronized context is created, and releases the lock when Dispose() is called. However, implementations based on immutable data structures are also possible.
Calling Synchronize() on an already synchronized context is possible, but has no effect. Only disposing the outermost ISynchronizedTypeResolveContext releases the lock.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.JumpType
member.summary: Describes the type of a control flow egde.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.JumpType.Normal
member.summary: A regular control flow edge.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.JumpType.JumpToExceptionHandler
member.summary: Jump to exception handler (an exception occurred)

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.JumpType.LeaveTry
member.summary: Jump from try block to leave target: This is not a real jump, as the finally handler is executed first!

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.JumpType.EndFinally
member.summary: Jump at endfinally (to any of the potential leave targets). For any leave-instruction, control flow enters the finally block - the edge to the leave target (LeaveTry) is not a real control flow edge. EndFinally edges are inserted at the end of the finally block, jumping to any of the targets of the leave instruction. This edge type is only used when copying of finally blocks is disabled (with copying, a normal deterministic edge is used at each copy of the endfinally node).

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowEdge
member.summary: Represents an edge in the control flow graph, pointing from Source to Target.

member.summary: Contains the control flow graph.
member.remarks: Use ControlFlowGraph builder to create instances of the ControlFlowGraph.

member.summary: Resets "Visited" to false for all nodes in this graph.

member.summary: Computes the dominator tree.

member.summary: Builds the ControlFlowGraph.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowGraphBuilder.CopyFinallySubGraph(ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode,ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode,ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode)
member.summary: Creates a copy of all nodes pointing to 'end' and replaces those references with references to 'newEnd'. Nodes pointing to the copied node are copied recursively to update those references, too. This recursion stops at 'start'. The modified version of start is returned.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType
member.summary: Type of the control flow node

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.Normal
member.summary: A normal node represents a basic block.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.EntryPoint
member.summary: The entry point of the method.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.RegularExit
member.summary: The exit point of the method (every ret instruction branches to this node)

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.ExceptionalExit
member.summary: This node represents leaving a method irregularly by throwing an exception.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.CatchHandler
member.summary: This node is used as a header for exception handler blocks.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.FinallyOrFaultHandler
F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNodeType.EndFinallyOrFault
member.summary: This node is used as footer for finally blocks and fault blocks. Depending on the "copyFinallyBlocks" option used when creating the graph, it is connected with all leave targets using EndFinally edges (when not copying); or with a specific leave target using a normal edge (when copying). For fault blocks, an exception edge is used to represent the "re-throwing" of the exception.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode
member.summary: Represents a block in the control flow graph.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.BlockIndex
member.summary: Index of this node in the ControlFlowGraph.Nodes collection.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.Offset
member.summary: Gets the IL offset of this node.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.NodeType
member.summary: Type of the node.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.EndFinallyOrFaultNode
member.summary: If this node is a FinallyOrFaultHandler node, this field points to the corresponding EndFinallyOrFault node. Otherwise, this field is null.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.Visited
member.summary: Visited flag, used in various algorithms. Before using it in your algorithm, reset it to false by calling ControlFlowGraph.ResetVisited();

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.DominatorTreeChildren
member.summary: List of children in the dominator tree.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.DominanceFrontier
member.summary: The dominance frontier of this node. This is the set of nodes for which this node dominates a predecessor, but which are not strictly dominated by this node.
member.remarks: b.DominanceFrontier = { y in CFG; (exists p in predecessors(y): b dominates p) and not (b strictly dominates y)}

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.Start
member.summary: Start of code block represented by this node. Only set for nodetype == Normal.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.End
member.summary: End of the code block represented by this node. Only set for nodetype == Normal. The end is exclusive, the end instruction itself does not belong to this block.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.ExceptionHandler
member.summary: Gets the exception handler associated with this node. Only set for nodetype == CatchHandler or nodetype == FinallyOrFaultHandler.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.Incoming
member.summary: List of incoming control flow edges.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.Outgoing
member.summary: List of outgoing control flow edges.

member.summary: Any user data

member.summary: Gets whether this dominates .

member.summary: Gets whether this node is reachable. Requires that dominance is computed!

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlFlowNode.CopyFrom
member.summary: Signalizes that this node is a copy of another node.

member.summary: Gets the immediate dominator (the parent in the dominator tree). Null if dominance has not been calculated; or if the node is unreachable.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlStructure
member.summary:
Represents the structure detected by the .
This is a tree of ControlStructure nodes. Each node contains a set of CFG nodes, and every CFG node is contained in exactly one ControlStructure node.

member.summary: The nodes in this control structure.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlStructure.AllNodes
member.summary: The nodes in this control structure and in all child control structures.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlStructure.EntryPoint
member.summary: The entry point of this control structure.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.ControlStructure.ExceptionHandler
member.summary: The exception handler associated with this Try,Handler or Finally structure.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.OpCodeInfo
member.summary: Additional info about opcodes.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.OpCodeInfo.IsMoveInstruction
member.summary: 'Move' kind of instructions have one input (may be stack or local variable) and copy that value to all outputs (again stack or local variable).

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.OpCodeInfo.CanThrow
member.summary: Specifies whether this opcode is capable of throwing exceptions.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SimplifyByRefCalls
member.summary: This is a transformation working on SSA form. It removes ldloca instructions and replaces them with SpecialOpCode.PrepareByOutCall or SpecialOpCode.PrepareByRefCall. This then allows the variable that had its address taken to also be transformed into SSA.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaBlock
member.summary: A block in a control flow graph; with instructions represented by "SsaInstructions" (instructions use variables, no evaluation stack). Usually these variables are in SSA form to make analysis easier.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaBlock.BlockIndex
member.summary: The block index in the control flow graph. This correspons to the node index in ControlFlowGraph.Nodes, so it can be used to retrieve the original CFG node and look up additional information (e.g. dominance).

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaForm
member.summary: Represents a graph of SsaBlocks.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaFormBuilder
member.summary: Constructs "SsaForm" graph for a CFG. This class transforms the method from stack-based IL to a register-based IL language. Then it calls into TransformToSsa to convert the resulting graph to static single assignment form.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.None
member.summary: No special op code: SsaInstruction has a normal IL instruction

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.Phi
member.summary: Φ function: chooses the appropriate variable based on which CFG edge was used to enter this block

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.PrepareByRefCall
member.summary: Variable is read from before passing it by ref. This instruction constructs a managed reference to the variable.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.PrepareByOutCall
member.summary: This instruction constructs a managed reference to the variable. The variable is not really read from.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.PrepareForFieldAccess
member.summary: This instruction constructs a managed reference to the variable. The reference is used for a field access on a value type.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.WriteAfterByRefOrOutCall
member.summary: Variable is written to after passing it by ref or out.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.Uninitialized
member.summary: Variable is not initialized.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.Parameter
member.summary: Value is passed in as parameter

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.Exception
member.summary: Value is a caught exception. TypeOperand is set to the exception type.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SpecialOpCode.InitObj
member.summary: Initialize a value type. Unlike the real initobj instruction, this one does not take an address but assigns to the target variable. TypeOperand is set to the type being created.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaInstruction.Instruction
member.summary: The original IL instruction. May be null for "invented" instructions (SpecialOpCode != None).

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaInstruction.Prefixes
member.summary: Prefixes in front of the IL instruction.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaInstruction.TypeOperand
member.summary: Gets the type operand. This is used only in combination with some special opcodes.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaInstruction.IsMoveInstruction
member.summary: Gets whether this instruction is a simple assignment from one variable to another.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaOptimization
member.summary: Contains some very simple optimizations that work on the SSA form.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaOptimization.DirectlyStoreToVariables(ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaForm)
member.summary: When any instructions stores its result in a stack location that's used only once in a 'stloc' or 'starg' instruction, we optimize this to directly store in the target location. As optimization this is redundant (does the same as copy propagation), but it'll make us keep the variables named after locals instead of keeping the temps as using only the simple copy propagation would do.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaVariable
member.summary: Represents a variable used with the SsaInstruction register-based instructions. Despite what the name suggests, the variable is not necessarily in single-assignment form - take a look at "bool IsSingleAssignment".

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaVariable.IsSingleAssignment
member.summary: Gets whether this variable has only a single assignment. This field is initialized in TransformToSsa step.
member.remarks: Not all variables can be transformed to single assignment form: variables that have their address taken cannot be represented in SSA (although SimplifyByRefCalls will get rid of the address-taking instruction in almost all cases)

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaVariable.Definition
member.summary: Gets the instruction defining the variable. This field is initialized in TransformToSsa step. It is only set for variables with a single assignment.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.SsaVariable.Usage
member.summary: Gets the places where a variable is used. If a single instruction reads a variable 2 times (e.g. adding to itself), then it must be included 2 times in this list!

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.FlowAnalysis.TransformToSsa
member.summary: Convers a method to static single assignment form.

member.summary: Dictionary with default values.

member.summary: Get the first expression to be excecuted if the instruction pointer is at the end of the given node

member.summary: IL AST transformation that introduces array, object and collection initializers.

member.summary: Removes redundatant Br, Nop, Dup, Pop

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILAstOptimizer.IntroducePropertyAccessInstructions(ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILNode)
member.summary:
Converts call and callvirt instructions that read/write properties into CallGetter/CallSetter instructions.
CallGetter/CallSetter is used to allow the ILAst to represent "while ((SomeProperty = value) != null)".

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILAstOptimizer.SplitToBasicBlocks(ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILBlock)
member.summary: Group input into a set of blocks that can be later arbitraliby schufled. The method adds necessary branches to make control flow between blocks explicit and thus order independent.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILAstOptimizer.FlattenBasicBlocks(ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILNode)
member.summary: Flattens all nested basic blocks, except the the top level 'node' argument

member.summary: Reduce the nesting of conditions. It should be done on flat data that already had most gotos removed

member.summary: Can the expression be used as a statement in C#?

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILBasicBlock.Body
member.remarks: Body has to start with a label and end with unconditional control flow

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.DefaultValue
member.summary: Represents the 'default(T)' instruction.
member.remarks: Introduced by SimplifyLdObjAndStObj step

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.CompoundAssignment
member.summary: ILExpression with a single child: binary operator. This expression means that the binary operator will also assign the new value to its left-hand side. 'CompoundAssignment' must not be used for local variables, as inlining (and other) optimizations don't know that it modifies the variable.
member.remarks: Introduced by MakeCompoundAssignments step

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.PostIncrement
member.summary: Represents the post-increment operator. The first argument is the address of the variable to increment (ldloca instruction). The second arugment is the amount the variable is incremented by (ldc.i4 instruction)
member.remarks: Introduced by IntroducePostIncrement step

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.CallGetter
member.summary: Calls the getter of a static property (or indexer), or of an instance property on 'base'

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.CallvirtGetter
member.summary: Calls the getter of an instance property (or indexer)

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.CallSetter
member.summary: Calls the setter of a static property (or indexer), or of an instance property on 'base'
member.remarks: This allows us to represent "while ((SomeProperty = val) != null) {}"

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.CallvirtSetter
member.summary: Calls the setter of a instance property (or indexer)

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILCode.AddressOf
member.summary: Simulates getting the address of the argument instruction.
member.remarks: Used for postincrement for properties, and to represent the Address() method on multi-dimensional arrays. Also used when inlining a method call on a value type: "stloc(v, ...); call(M, ldloca(v));" becomes "call(M, AddressOf(...))"

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILInlining.InlineIfPossible(System.Collections.Generic.List{ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILNode},System.Int32@)
member.summary: Aggressively inlines the stloc instruction at block.Body[pos] into the next instruction, if possible. If inlining was possible; we will continue to inline (non-aggressively) into the the combined instruction.
member.remarks: After the operation, pos will point to the new combined instruction.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.Decompiler.ILAst.ILInlining.CopyPropagation
member.summary: Runs a very simple form of copy propagation. Copy propagation is used in two cases: 1) assignments from arguments to local variables If the target variable is assigned to only once (so always is that argument) and the argument is never changed (no ldarga/starg), then we can replace the variable with the argument. 2) assignments of address-loading instructions to local variables

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.InsertParenthesesVisitor
member.summary: Inserts the parentheses into the AST that are needed to ensure the AST can be printed correctly. For example, if the AST contains BinaryOperatorExpresson(2, Mul, BinaryOperatorExpression(1, Add, 1))); printing that AST would incorrectly result in "2 * 1 + 1". By running InsertParenthesesVisitor, the necessary parentheses are inserted: "2 * (1 + 1)".

member.summary: Parenthesizes the expression if it does not have the minimum required precedence.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.InsertParenthesesVisitor.InsertParenthesesForReadability
member.summary: Gets/Sets whether the visitor should insert parentheses to make the code better looking. If this property is false, it will insert parentheses only where strictly required by the language spec.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.Expression
member.remarks: Base class for expressions

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Expression.DoResolve(Mono.CSharp.ResolveContext)
member.summary: Performs semantic analysis on the Expression
member.remarks:
The Resolve method is invoked to perform the semantic analysis on the node.
The return value is an expression (it can be the same expression in some cases) or a new expression that better represents this node.
For example, optimizations of Unary (LiteralInt) would return a new LiteralInt with a negated value.
If there is an error during semantic analysis, then an error should be reported (using Report) and a null value should be returned.
There are two side effects expected from calling Resolve(): the the field variable "eclass" should be set to any value of the enumeration `ExprClass' and the type variable should be set to a valid type (this is the type of the expression).

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Expression.Resolve(Mono.CSharp.ResolveContext,Mono.CSharp.ResolveFlags)
member.summary: Resolves an expression and performs semantic analysis on it.
member.remarks: Currently Resolve wraps DoResolve to perform sanity checking and assertion checking on what we expect from Resolve.

member.summary: Resolves an expression and performs semantic analysis on it.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.MethodOrOperator.ConditionalConditions
member.summary: Returns true if method has conditional attribute and the conditions is not defined (method is excluded).

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.IAssignMethod
member.summary: This interface is implemented by expressions that can be assigned to.
member.remarks:
This interface is implemented by Expressions whose values can not store the result on the top of the stack.
Expressions implementing this (Properties, Indexers and Arrays) would perform an assignment of the Expression "source" into its final location.
No values on the top of the stack are expected to be left by invoking this method.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.IMemoryLocation
member.summary: This interface is implemented by variables

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.IMemoryLocation.AddressOf(Mono.CSharp.EmitContext,Mono.CSharp.AddressOp)
member.summary:
The AddressOf method should generate code that loads the address of the object and leaves it on the stack.
The `mode' argument is used to notify the expression of whether this will be used to read from the address or write to the address.
This is just a hint that can be used to provide good error reporting, and should have no other side effects.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.LocalTemporary
member.summary: An Expression to hold a temporary value.
member.remarks:
The LocalTemporary class is used to hold temporary values of a given type to "simulate" the expression semantics. The local variable is never captured.
The local temporary is used to alter the normal flow of code generation basically it creates a local variable, and its emit instruction generates code to access this value, return its address or save its value.
If `is_address' is true, then the value that we store is the address to the real value, and not the value itself.
This is needed for a value type, because otherwise you just end up making a copy of the value on the stack and modifying it. You really need a pointer to the origional value so that you can modify it in that location. This Does not happen with a class because a class is a pointer -- so you always get the indirection.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Convert.ImplicitConversionStandard(Mono.CSharp.ResolveContext,Mono.CSharp.Expression,Mono.CSharp.TypeSpec,Mono.CSharp.Location)
member.summary:
Attempts to apply the `Standard Implicit Conversion' rules to the expression `expr' into the `target_type'. It returns a new expression that can be used in a context that expects a `target_type'.
This is different from `ImplicitConversion' in that the user defined implicit conversions are excluded.

member.summary: Attempts to implicitly convert `source' into `target_type', using ImplicitConversion. If there is no implicit conversion, then an error is signaled

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Convert.ExplicitNumericConversion(Mono.CSharp.ResolveContext,Mono.CSharp.Expression,Mono.CSharp.TypeSpec)
member.summary:
Performs the explicit numeric conversions
There are a few conversions that are not part of the C# standard, they were interim hacks in the C# compiler that were supposed to become explicit operators in the UIntPtr class and IntPtr class, but for historical reasons it did not happen, so the C# compiler ended up with these special hacks.
See bug 59800 for details.
The conversion are: UIntPtr->SByte UIntPtr->Int16 UIntPtr->Int32 IntPtr->UInt64 UInt64->IntPtr SByte->UIntPtr Int16->UIntPtr

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.TypeCast
member.summary:
This kind of cast is used to encapsulate the child whose type is child.Type into an expression that is reported to return "return_type". This is used to encapsulate expressions which have compatible types, but need to be dealt at higher levels with.
For example, a "byte" expression could be encapsulated in one of these as an "unsigned int". The type for the expression would be "unsigned int".

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.BoxedCast
member.summary:
This kind of cast is used to encapsulate Value Types in objects.
The effect of it is to box the value type emitted by the previous operation.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator
member.summary: Evaluator: provides an API to evaluate C# statements and expressions dynamically.
member.remarks:
This class exposes static methods to evaluate expressions in the current program.
To initialize the evaluator with a number of compiler options call the Init(string[]args) method with a set of command line options that the compiler recognizes.
To interrupt execution of a statement, you can invoke the Evaluator.Interrupt method.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.QuitValue
member.summary: A sentinel value used to indicate that no value was was set by the compiled function. This is used to differentiate between a function not returning a value and null.

member.name: F:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.DescribeTypeExpressions
member.summary: If true, turns type expressions into valid expressions and calls the describe method on it

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Interrupt
member.summary: Interrupts the evaluation of an expression executing in Evaluate.
member.remarks: Use this method to interrupt long-running invocations.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Compile(System.String,Mono.CSharp.CompiledMethod@)
member.summary: Compiles the input string and returns a delegate that represents the compiled code.
member.remarks:
Compiles the input string as a C# expression or statement, unlike the Evaluate method, the resulting delegate can be invoked multiple times without incurring in the compilation overhead.
If the return value of this function is null, this indicates that the parsing was complete. If the return value is a string it indicates that the input string was partial and that the invoking code should provide more code before the code can be successfully compiled.
If you know that you will always get full expressions or statements and do not care about partial input, you can use the other Compile overload.
On success, in addition to returning null, the compiled parameter will be set to the delegate that can be invoked to execute the code.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Compile(System.String)
member.summary: Compiles the input string and returns a delegate that represents the compiled code.
member.remarks:
Compiles the input string as a C# expression or statement, unlike the Evaluate method, the resulting delegate can be invoked multiple times without incurring in the compilation overhead.
This method can only deal with fully formed input strings and does not provide a completion mechanism. If you must deal with partial input (for example for interactive use) use the other overload.
On success, a delegate is returned that can be used to invoke the method.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Evaluate(System.String,System.Object@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Evaluates and expression or statement and returns any result values.
member.remarks:
Evaluates the input string as a C# expression or statement. If the input string is an expression the result will be stored in the result variable and the result_set variable will be set to true.
It is necessary to use the result/result_set pair to identify when a result was set (for example, execution of user-provided input can be an expression, a statement or others, and result_set would only be set if the input was an expression.
If the return value of this function is null, this indicates that the parsing was complete. If the return value is a string, it indicates that the input is partial and that the user should provide an updated string.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Run(System.String)
member.summary: Executes the given expression or statement.
member.remarks: Executes the provided statement, returns true on success, false on parsing errors. Exceptions might be thrown by the called code.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.Evaluate(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates and expression or statement and returns the result.
member.remarks:
Evaluates the input string as a C# expression or statement and returns the value.
This method will throw an exception if there is a syntax error, of if the provided input is not an expression but a statement.

member.summary: Loads the given assembly and exposes the API to the user.

member.summary: Exposes the API of the given assembly to the Evaluator

member.name: P:Mono.CSharp.Evaluator.InteractiveBaseClass
member.summary: The base class for the classes that host the user generated code
member.remarks:
This is the base class that will host the code executed by the Evaluator. By default this is the Mono.CSharp.InteractiveBase class which is useful for interactive use.
By changing this property you can control the base class and the static members that are available to your evaluated code.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.CompiledMethod

member.remarks: Since the Compile methods will compile statements and expressions into the same delegate, you can tell if a value was returned by checking whether the returned value is of type NoValueSet.

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.Invocation.EmitCall(Mono.CSharp.EmitContext,Mono.CSharp.Expression,Mono.CSharp.MethodSpec,Mono.CSharp.Arguments,Mono.CSharp.Location)
member.remarks:
is_base tells whether we want to force the use of the `call' opcode instead of using callvirt. Call is required to call a specific method, while callvirt will always use the most recent method in the vtable.
is_static tells whether this is an invocation on a static method
instance_expr is an expression that represents the instance it must be non-null if is_static is false.
method is the method to invoke.
Arguments is the list of arguments to pass to the method or constructor.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.Block
member.summary: Block represents a C# block.
member.remarks:
This class is used in a number of places: either to represent explicit blocks that the programmer places or implicit blocks.
Implicit blocks are used as labels or to introduce variable declarations.
Top-level blocks derive from Block, and they are called ToplevelBlock they contain extra information that is not necessary on normal blocks.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.Location
member.summary: Keeps track of the location in the program
member.remarks:
This uses a compact representation and a couple of auxiliary structures to keep track of tokens to (file,line and column) mappings. The usage of the bits is:
- 16 bits for "checkpoint" which is a mixed concept of file and "line segment" - 8 bits for line delta (offset) from the line segment - 8 bits for column number.
http://lists.ximian.com/pipermail/mono-devel-list/2004-December/009508.html

member.summary: Whether the specified method is an interface method implementation

member.name: M:Mono.CSharp.PendingImplementation.InterfaceMethod(Mono.CSharp.MemberName,Mono.CSharp.TypeSpec,Mono.CSharp.MethodData,Mono.CSharp.PendingImplementation.Operation)
member.remarks:
If a method in Type `t' (or null to look in all interfaces and the base abstract class) with name `Name', return type `ret_type' and arguments `args' implements an interface, this method will return the MethodInfo that this method implements.
If `name' is null, we operate solely on the method's signature. This is for instance used when implementing indexers.
The `Operation op' controls whether to lookup, clear the pending bit, or clear all the methods with the given signature.
The `MethodInfo need_proxy' is used when we're implementing an interface's indexer in a class. If the new indexer's IndexerName does not match the one that was used in the interface, then we always need to create a proxy for it.

member.name: T:Mono.CSharp.SeekableStreamReader
member.summary:
This is an arbitrarily seekable StreamReader wrapper.
It uses a self-tuning buffer to cache the seekable data, but if the seek is too far, it may read the underly stream all over from the beginning.

member.name: P:Mono.CSharp.SeekableStreamReader.Position
member.remarks: This value corresponds to the current position in a stream of characters. The StreamReader hides its manipulation of the underlying byte stream and all character set/decoding issues. Thus, we cannot use this position to guess at the corresponding position in the underlying byte stream even though there is a correlation between them.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.Resolver.ResolveVisitor
member.summary: Traverses the DOM and resolves expressions.
member.remarks:
The ResolveVisitor does two jobs at the same time: it tracks the resolve context (properties on CSharpResolver) and it resolves the expressions visited. To allow using the context tracking without having to resolve every expression in the file (e.g. when you want to resolve only a single node deep within the DOM), you can use the interface. The navigator allows you to switch the between scanning mode and resolving mode. In scanning mode, the context is tracked (local variables registered etc.), but nodes are not resolved. While scanning, the navigator will get asked about every node that the resolve visitor is about to enter. This allows the navigator whether to keep scanning, whether switch to resolving mode, or whether to completely skip the subtree rooted at that node.
In resolving mode, the context is tracked and nodes will be resolved. The resolve visitor may decide that it needs to resolve other nodes as well in order to resolve the current node. In this case, those nodes will be resolved automatically, without asking the navigator interface. For child nodes that are not essential to resolving, the resolve visitor will switch back to scanning mode (and thus will ask the navigator for further instructions).
Moreover, there is the ResolveAll mode - it works similar to resolving mode, but will not switch back to scanning mode. The whole subtree will be resolved without notifying the navigator.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.Resolver.ResolveVisitor.#ctor(ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.Resolver.CSharpResolver,ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.ParsedFile,ICSharpCode.NRefactory.CSharp.Resolver.IResolveVisitorNavigator)
member.summary: Creates a new ResolveVisitor instance.
member.param: The CSharpResolver, describing the initial resolve context. If you visit a whole CompilationUnit with the resolve visitor, you can simply pass new CSharpResolver(typeResolveContext) without setting up the context. If you only visit a subtree, you need to pass a CSharpResolver initialized to the context for that subtree.

Result of the for the file being passed. This is used for setting up the context on the resolver. You may pass null if you are only visiting a part of a method body and have already set up the context in the .
The navigator, which controls where the resolve visitor will switch between scanning mode and resolving mode. If you pass null, then ResolveAll mode will be used.

member.summary: Gets the cached resolve result for the specified node. Returns null if no cached result was found (e.g. if the node was not visited; or if it was visited in scanning mode).

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.TypeSystem.IInterningProvider
member.summary: Provider used for interning.
member.remarks:
A simple IInterningProvider implementation could use 3 dictionaries: 1. using value equality comparer (for certain types known to implement value equality, e.g. string and IType) 2. using comparer that calls into ISupportsInterning (for types implementing ISupportsInterning) 3. list comparer (for InternList method)
On the first Intern()-call, the provider tells the object to prepare for interning (ISupportsInterning.PrepareForInterning) and stores it into a dictionary. On further Intern() calls, the original object is returned for all equal objects. This allows reducing the memory usage by using a single object instance where possible.
Interning provider implementations could also use the interning logic for different purposes: for example, it could be used to determine which objects are used jointly between multiple type definitions and which are used only within a single type definition. Then a persistent file format could be organized so that shared objects are loaded only once, yet non-shared objects get loaded lazily together with the class.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.TypeSystem.IInterningProvider.Intern``1(``0)
member.summary: Interns the specified object. The object must implement , or must be of one of the types known to the interning provider to use value equality, otherwise it will be returned without being interned.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.Utils.CSharpPrimitiveCast
member.summary: Static helper method for converting between primitive types.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.NRefactory.Utils.CSharpPrimitiveCast.Cast(System.TypeCode,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs a conversion between primitive types. Unfortunately we cannot use Convert.ChangeType because it has different semantics (e.g. rounding behavior for floats, overflow, etc.), so we write down every possible primitive C# cast and let the compiler figure out the exact semantics. And we have to do everything twice, once in a checked-block, once in an unchecked-block.
